results.abstract: Pavel Popovich, fourth Soviet astronaut to go into space, dies at age 79 (M)

headline.main: Pavel Popovich, 79, a Pioneer In Space for the Soviet Union

results.snippet: Mr. Popovich is best known for piloting one of the first two manned satellites to orbit the earth at the same time, a trip that made him the sixth person in orbit.
results.lead_paragraph: Pavel Popovich, the fourth Soviet man to go to space, died Wednesday in Crimea. He was 79. His death, at a sanitarium, was announced by the head of the federation of astronauts, Vladimir Kovalenok. Itar-Tass quoted sources as saying that Mr. Popovich died of a stroke. He was five days short of his 80th birthday.

results.abstract: Judge in Orlando rules that lawyers for Lisa Nowak, former astronaut charged with attacking romantic rival Colleen Shipman, may depose Shipman for second time to determine if she was actually touched by pepper spray during confrontation; lawyers want one of Nowak's charges thrown out if Shipman was not harmed by spray; photo (S)

headline.main: Florida: Decision on Questioning In Case of Former Astronaut

results.snippet: Lawyers for the former astronaut Lisa Nowak will get another chance to question a romantic rival she is accused of driving 1,000 miles to confront. Ms. Nowak is charged with attacking Colleen Shipman in a Florida airport parking lot two years ago....
results.lead_paragraph: Lawyers for the former astronaut Lisa Nowak will get another chance to question a romantic rival she is accused of driving 1,000 miles to confront. Ms. Nowak is charged with attacking Colleen Shipman in a Florida airport parking lot two years ago. Ms. Shipman had begun dating Ms. Nowak's love interest, Bill Oefelein, a former space shuttle pilot. A judge in Orlando ruled that Ms. Nowak's lawyers could depose Ms. Shipman for a second time to determine if she was actually touched by pepper spray during the confrontation. Ms. Nowak's lawyers have a report from emergency technicians that raises questions about whether Ms. Shipman was sprayed. The issue is important because Ms. Nowak's lawyers want one of her criminal charges thrown out if Ms. Shipman was not harmed by the spray. Ms. Nowak, above, was not in court for the hearing.

headline.main: They'll Take Manhattan, Isle of Whimsy and Virtual Reality

results.snippet: This new novel pretentiously  and clumsily  tries to create a kind of virtual-reality game version of Manhattan.
results.lead_paragraph: CHRONIC CITY By By Jonathan Lethem

results.abstract: rodger doxsey, 62, astronomer who worked on the hubb¿

headline.main: Rodger Doxsey, 62, Astronomer Who Worked on the Hubble, Dies

results.snippet: Dr. Doxsey, the head of mission operations at the Space Telescope Science Institute in Baltimore, helped keep the space telescope working at peak performance.
results.lead_paragraph: Rodger Doxsey, an astronomer who played a crucial below-the-decks role in keeping the Hubble Space Telescope flying and doing science in good times and bad for almost 20 years, died Tuesday in Towson, Md. He was 62 and lived in Towson. His death, in a hospice after a long battle with cancer, was announced by the Space Telescope Science Institute in Baltimore.

results.abstract: A Houston start-up company, founded by a NASA astronaut, is hoping that its business providing water purification systems in Africa will become self-sustaining by selling carbon credits.

headline.main: Astronaut Targets Drinking Water in Rwanda - and Carbon Credits for Revenues

results.snippet: A Houston start-up company, founded by a NASA astronaut, is hoping that its business providing water purification systems in Africa will become self-sustaining by selling carbon credits.
results.lead_paragraph: In keeping with the rising tide of businesses tapping into potentially lucrative markets at the bottom of the economic pyramid, Manna Energy is seeking to turn a profit -- someday -- by bringing safe drinking water to Rwandan schools.

results.abstract: Vic Mizzy, writer of television theme songs, dies at age 93; photo (M)

headline.main: Vic Mizzy, 93, Songwriter Of 'Addams Family' Fame

results.snippet: Mr. Mizzy wrote the infernally catchy themes for the 1960s television comedies “The Addams Family” and “Green Acres.”
results.lead_paragraph: Vic Mizzy, whose infernally catchy themes for the television comedies ''The Addams Family'' and ''Green Acres'' are as entrenched in the memories of Americans who grew up in the 1960s as any pop tune or protest anthem, died on Saturday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 93. The cause was heart failure, said his daughter Lynn Mizzy Jonas.

results.abstract: Blue-ribbon panel says that National Aeronautics and Space Administration should consider scrapping rocket it has been developing to replace space shuttles and bypassing Moon for now, move that would set stage for major overhaul of nation's human spaceflight program; most options proposed in report turn to private companies to provide astronauts with ride to low-Earth orbit and replace Moon landings with deep-space visits that do not require development of complicated landers; photo (M)

headline.main: For NASA, Possible Shifts in Direction

results.snippet: A report from a 10-member group said the Ares I was a victim of smaller-than-expected budgets and changing circumstances.
results.lead_paragraph: Setting the stage for a major overhaul of the nation's human spaceflight program, a blue-ribbon panel said Thursday that the National Aeronautics and Space Administration should consider scrapping the rocket it had been developing to replace the space shuttles and bypassing the Moon for now. In a 157-page report titled ''Seeking a Human Spaceflight Program Worthy of a Great Nation,'' most of the options proposed by the 10-member panel turn to private companies to provide astronauts with the ride to low-Earth orbit and replace Moon landings with the ''flexible path'' approach -- flybys of the Moon and Mars and visits to asteroids and deep-space locales that do not require development of complicated landers.

headline.kicker: THEATER REVIEW | 'I GOT SICK THEN I GOT BETTER'
headline.main: The Irritating Turns On a Road to Recovery

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: I GOT SICK THEN I GOT BETTER (PLAY)

results.snippet: “I Got Sick Then I Got Better,” which just moved to East Fourth Street Theater, is Jenny Allen’s embraceable one-woman show about having a life-threatening cancer.
results.lead_paragraph: ''You look great.'' Now that's a sentence, you would think, to warm the heart of a woman who admits that she is ever hungry for reassurance. But as Jenny Allen delivers it again and again, with a variety of inflections, this most customary of compliments starts to sound like fightin' words. In ''I Got Sick Then I Got Better,'' her embraceable one-woman show about having a life-threatening cancer, Ms. Allen speaks with passion and precision about the forms of being told how well she looked when she was undergoing chemotherapy. Her analyses should be collected into a special book of grammar.

results.abstract: Gregory Cowles reviews book Chronic City by Jonathan Lethem; drawing (M)
results.snippet: This exuberant novel set in a drug-addled, alternate-reality Manhattan is at its heart a traditional story of moral and intellectual development.
